newsitem.title: USA: U.S. manufacturing surges, economy adds momentum.
newsitem.headline: U.S. manufacturing surges, economy adds momentum.

text.p: Manufacturing gained steam in March, a key private-sector report released on Tuesday showed, yet there was no sign of troubling price pressures as financial markets were roiled again by fear of more interest rate rises.

The National Association of Purchasing Management, whose members buy raw materials for the nation's factories, said its index of manufacturing activity climbed to 55.0 in March -- the highest since February 1995 when it was also at that level -- from 53.1 in February.
A reading above 50 in the index shows expanding activity. March was the 71st straight month -- nearly six years -- in which the manufacturing index indicated growth.
The purchasing managers' summary was one of a trio of reports that further demonstrated the economy's vitality as it completed six years of steady expansion last month.

It was intensely awaited by analysts after two days of steep stock market losses since the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates last week as a preemptive strike against inflation. Its price index dropped to 50.9 percent from 55.1 percent, reflecting a slower rate of inflation.
Nonetheless, stock prices fell on Tuesday, though bond prices steadied.

Separately, the Commerce Department said spending on new construction increased in February at the briskest rate in nearly a year, up 2.3 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $603.8 billion after a 0.3 percent January gain.
Milder-than-normal weather after a bitter January boosted building activity across the board for private and government-financed projects from new housing to offices and water treatment plants.

A third report from the Conference Board showed its broad-based index of leading indicators flashing a green light for steady growth as it rose 0.5 percent in February after a 0.3 percent gain in January.
The February rise in the index, which is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months ahead, was the largest since a 0.9 percent rise last February, the business research group said.
"The economy is showing solid growth with inflation still well-contained," said economist Lynn Reaser of Barnett Banks Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla.
"But the economy, in terms of labour markets, is at full employment," Reaser added. "The risk is still on the side of higher inflation rather than recession."

The Federal Reserve cited its concern about strong demand last week when it announced a quarter percentage point rise in short-term interest rates. Many analysts expect more rate rises later this year until the central bank is convinced that costlier credit is putting a brake on demand.
The purchasing managers' report showed gains in new orders, tighter supplier deliveries, rising employment and more export orders last month that suggest continuing momentum for the economy.

"Clearly these numbers are pointing to stronger growth through the second quarter," said economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. in New York, possibly three consecutive quarters of expansion at a 3 percent to 4 percent annual rate.

"That's far in excess of the economy's long-term potential," Jones added. The Fed has set a target of around 2 percent to 2-1/4 percent as its ideal level for sustained increases in national output without risking an inflationary flare-up in wages and prices.
The February leading index, seen as an indicator of the economy's direction, was broadly higher with nine of its 10 separate component measures turning up from January.
The largest contributors to the overall gain were fewer unemployment claims and slower deliveries, which suggested that suppliers were having a harder time meeting brisk demand.
The Commerce Department's finding that February construction picked up was anticipated because it was previously reported that there was a bulge in hiring for construction jobs during the month.

The size of the gain, however, was larger than anticipated. The department said it was the biggest surge in construction spending since a matching 2.3 percent rise in March of last year. The last time there was a bigger spending jump was nearly three years ago, in March 1994, when it gained 3.4 percent.
Privately financed building rose 1.8 percent to $456 billion a year in February after a 0.6 percent January gain.

Government spending on construction projects surged 4.1 percent to a rate of $147.9 billion in February after a 0.4 percent fall in January. Spending was up on public housing projects, for schools, highways and streets, sewers and water treatment plants.
